> >On Mon, 02 Aug 2004 22:33:46 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Well, it would require a more complex network to handle variance.
> Whether such a network could be found I don't know.

Well, if there is, we'd like to find it. :)

Floreano has published research in which a roving eye, or active
vision system, scans a visual field in which either an isoceles
triangle or a square is generated.  The size and position of the
generated images also vary randomly, and a certain amount of pixelated
noise is added to the visual field as well.  The evolved networks were
apparently able to achieve 100% accuracy in discriminating between 10
random triangles and 10 random squares.

A link to the paper is here:

http://asl.epfl.ch/member.php?SCIPER=111729

And the name of it is "Coevolution of active vision and feature
selection".  A similar approach should be feasible for OCR or other
imaging applications, I think.

> Have you decided on a resolution/size for your roving eye yet?

We're in the process of trying out different sized eyes (3x3, 5x5, etc.).

> Therefore if I was going to try and construct a
> robust OCR network I think I'd tend towards a roving eye with quite a
> high resolution(good enough to distinguish all of the characters anyhow)
> that could see whole characters at a time - but then could rove (move
> and zoom in/out) in order to frame characters within the eye's field of
> view. 

Well, the problem is that as the size of the eye increases, the size
of the controlling ANN increases exponentially.  We may try some very
large resolution eyes, though, to see if there's a measurable increase
in performance.

Derek
